awd_titl_txt: Selected Topics in Quark Flavor, Neutrino and Higgs physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Alakabha Datta at the University of Mississippi.

The Standard Model of particle physics is built around the observation that nature contains three separate generations of quarks and leptons.  These generations of particles all appear identical in terms of their charges and interactions, and differ only in their masses.  They also mix amongst each other in non-trivial ways that lead to CP violation.  ``Flavor physics'' is a general term that encapsulates the physics of this generational structure, and there is currently a huge amount of data from flavor experiments. In his research, Professor Datta aims to develop methods that will help to distinguish different new physics models by using this data. He also plans to use flavor symmetries in order to understand the origin of quark and lepton mixing, and he intends to study processes that can probe non-standard couplings of the Higgs boson.

The project is also expected to have significant broader impacts. Professor Datta will involve a graduate student in his research, thereby providing training to a junior physicist beginning research in the field of flavor and Higgs physics.  Professor Datta also plans to give talks about his research at various colleges and high schools in Mississippi and surrounding areas with the aim of attracting students from under-represented groups to scientific research.

The project was submitted by Alakabha Datta who was the Principal Investigator(PI) for the project. The title of the project was
" Selected Topics in Quark Flavor, Neutrino and Higgs Physics.".

Particle physics is an attempt to understand the basic building blocks of matter that make up the Universe and the forces that hold matter together. Scientists have made good progress in understanding three out of the four basic forces of nature. The theory of the three forces, the electromagnetic force, the weak nuclear force and the strong nuclear force is called the Standard Model (SM). The fourth force, gravity, is still not understood as well as the other forces and is not part of the Standard Model. The Standard Model also does not explain the observed dark matter and dark energy in the Universe. In fact, the Standard Model can only explain the behavior of about 5 percent of material that make up the Universe. The Standard Model also cannot explain the observed matter-antimatter asymmetry in the Universe which is  responsible for our existence. This asymmetry results from the violation of a fundamental symmetry in nature called CP. CP which is charge Conjugation- Parity is a symmetry which says the laws of nature remain unchanged if we replace all particles with their antiparticles and interchange left with right. Most extensions of the SM contain new CP violating sources which do not have to be small as CP is not an exact or approximates symmetry of nature.  

Because of the many shortcomings of the Standard Model, scientists generally believe that has to be new physics or new laws of physics  that have not been discovered yet, that will help us understand the various unexplained observations. Most work in particle physics is trying to find this new physics so we can have a better understanding of the Universe.  Many groups are involved in  this huge effort and many different processes are being studied to find the new laws of physics. The goal of the project was to contribute to this effort by focusing on a set of specific processes that involve quarks, neutrinos and the Higgs boson. In the quark sector the project was specially interested in particles mabe of the $b$ quark. These particles are produced in large numbers at experiments called the B factories. The B factories at Babar, USA, LHCb at CERN, Geneva and Belle, JAPAN, in certain cases have  observed deviations from the Standard Model predictions in processes which are known to be very sensitive to new physics effects and new sources of CP violation.

In recent years, there have been several measurements  in $B$ decays which differ from the predictions of the Standard Model
(SM) by $\sim 2\sigma$. These deviations, if real, will be confirmed in future experiments. One of the main activities of the project was to analyze data from the  $B$ physics experiments. Several interesting results were announced by the B factory experiments and we took the leading role is trying to understand the results  in terms of new laws of physics. We also proposed new tests that could shed further light on the nature of these new physical laws. May of our suggestions have been included in the experimental program and many of them are being implemented.

Another building block of our Universe are particles called neutrinos and their associated charged leptons such as the electron , muon and the tau particle. The project proposed new ideas to understand the properties of these particles in multi-Higgs models where there are several Higgs bosons . The project studied non standard model interactions of neutrinos. Our proposals have recieved attention from a proposed experiment at CERN.
